Notes.Comprehensive Statutroy Acts & Legal Fra: This matrix outlines the key Statutory Acts & Legal References for statutory PAYE tax limits, rates, levies and reliefts.
Income Tax Act  (Cap 332, Laws of Tanzania)

Notes.Column3: Limit
None. PAYE applies via resident bands (top rate 30%) and a flat 15% on employment income of non-residents (final tax).
Typically excluded if it’s an actual reimbursement or employer policy paid for work purposes; otherwise taxable. (No statutory shilling cap stated in the Act; apply general benefit rules.)

Notes.Comprehensive Statutroy Acts & Legal Fra: Business travel & accommodation (in course of duty)
Notes.Column3: Excluded where incurred/likely to be incurred in performing duties (documented).
Taxable benefit = lower of (i) market rent or (ii) employer’s cost; less any employee contribution.
Taxable annual value by engine size & age (e.g., ≤1000cc: TZS 250k if <5 yrs / 125k if >5 yrs; >3000cc: 1.5m / 750k).
Taxable benefit = difference between statutory/market rate and actual rate; include in PAYE base. (No fixed TZS cap; apply ITA method.)
The “tax benefit” is grossed-up at 330% of tax paid on behalf of the employee (special quantification rule).

Notes.Comprehensive Statutroy Acts & Legal Fra: The National Security Fund Act, 1997and National Social Security Fund (Amendment) Act, 2018 (NSSF NO. 50 of 2018)

Notes.Column3: Limit
Total 20% of employee’s gross salary (private sector). Employer may: 10% + 10%, or 15% employer + 5% employee, or remit full 20%. Employee share must not exceed 10%.

Notes.Comprehensive Statutroy Acts & Legal Fra: National Health Insurance Fund (NHIF) Act of Tanzania (NHIF Act No. 8 of 1999) and  Universal Health Coverage (UHC) Bill in 2022

Notes.Column3: Limit
Common payroll configuration: 3% employer + 3% employee of monthly salary (legacy NHIF for PUBLIC sector employees).

Mandates health insurance and obligates formal-sector employers to contribute; implementation details and exact payroll mechanics are being operationalised.  Universal Health Coverage (UHC) Bill in 2022
Limit
Mainland: 3.5% of monthly gross emoluments (employers with ≥10 employees). Zanzibar: 4%. Employer-paid.
Typical employer rate around 0.6% of cash wages.
Limit
Not applicable in Tanzania (Kenya-specific.)
Limit

Public employees contribute under PSSSF; rates and rules differ from NSSF (outside private-sector scope here).

The Public Service Social Security Fund (PSSSF) in Tanzania has a total contribution rate of 20% of the employee's monthly basic salary. This total is split between the employer and the employee as follows: 
Employer Contribution: 15% of the employee's monthly salary
Employee Contribution: 5% of the employee's monthly salary, which is deducted from their pay 
These rates are based on the employee's basic salary, excluding bonuses, overtime pay, or allowances. The employer is responsible for remitting the total 20% contribution to the PSSSF by the last day of the following month.
Limit

Notes.Comprehensive Statutroy Acts & Legal Fra: Permitted deductions (taxes, NSSF, agreed items, court orders, etc.)
Notes.Column3: Deductions must be permitted by law/contract/consent; unlawful deductions are prohibited.
If recovering an advance, each instalment must not exceed one-third of the employee’s wage for the pay period.
Treat as advance on wages already earned/due with written employee consent and payslip disclosure (not a loan). Ensure compliance with the 1/3 per-instalment cap when recovering advances.
Traditional Loan

Notes.Column2: Employee’s already earned salary (portion of wages due)
Notes.Column3: Third-party credit not yet earned

Notes.Column2: Advance on wages under the ELRA Act
Notes.Column3: Credit facility under the Bank of Tanzania Act, the Microfinance Act, 2018, or other banking laws.

Notes.Column2: Typically a small facilitation or service fee (not interest)
Notes.Column3: Interest-bearing under the Microfinance Act, 2018 or Banking and Financial Institutions Act, 2006.

Notes.Column2: Automatically deducted from future salary payment
Notes.Column3: Paid over time from future income according to agreed loan repayment terms.

Notes.Column2:
Bank of Tanzania (BoT) — under the National Payment Systems Act, 2015 for fintechs that process wage disbursements or payments.
Ministry of Labour, Youth, Employment and Persons with Disability — under the Employment and Labour Relations Act, 2004 for compliance with wage deduction and advance rules (particularly the 1/3 recovery cap per pay period).
Notes.Column3: Bank of Tanzania (BoT) — under the Banking and Financial Institutions Act, 2006 and the Microfinance Act, 2018 for loan, credit, or microfinance activities.
